value.textLabel: Welcome! Rust is a systems programming language focused on speed, memory safety, and concurrency. It is used to build operating systems, game engines, command-line tools, and high-performance backend services.

Rust is a statically-typed language that compiles to machine code. It enforces memory safety (preventing segfaults and data races) without a garbage collector, using a unique 'ownership' and 'borrowing' system.

Rust is widely used because:
• C-like performance
• Guaranteed memory safety
• Fearless concurrency
• Modern tooling (Cargo package manager)
• Helpful compiler error messages
To install Rust, the official method is using `rustup`, the Rust toolchain installer. After installation, verify it using the command:
Rust syntax defines rules on how Rust code must be written. Rust is expression-based, case-sensitive, and uses macros (like println!) for common tasks.

Key Rust syntax elements:
• Functions are defined with `fn`
• `main` is the entry point
• `println!` is a macro (note the !)
• Statements end with semicolons
• Blocks use curly braces
Rust I/O (Input / Output) uses the `std::io` module. Reading user input is explicit and must handle potential errors.

value.textLabel: Rust is a statically typed language. It has two major data type categories: scalar and compound.

Scalar types:
Integers (i32, u64, etc.), Floats (f32, f64), Booleans (bool), Characters (char)
Type casting converts a value from one type to another. Rust does not perform automatic 'widening' casting; all casting is done explicitly with the `as` keyword.
Operators allow you to perform actions on variables. They include arithmetic, logical, comparison, and bitwise operators.
